question_details.title: Will the following companies be added to the S&P 500 before October 2025? (HOOD)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-24 20:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38681). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The [S\&P 500 Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_500) is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. The index is maintained by [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_Dow_Jones_Indices), and inclusion decisions are based on factors such as market capitalization, liquidity, financial viability, and sector representation. Current index constituents can be viewed [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies#S\&P_500_component_stocks).

S\&P 500 membership is valued by corporations because it indicates success and boosts brand awareness.

To join S\&P 500 a company must fulfill the following requirements:

* It must have a market capitalization of at least \$20.5 billion.
* It must be domiciled in the U.S.
* It must be a corporation whose shares are listed on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq system, or one of the CBOE exchanges.
* It can not be a limited partnership, master limited partnership, closed-end fund, limited liability company, special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

Five possible candidates to be added to the S\&P 500 in over the following months are:

* [ARES (Ares Management Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares_Management): A global alternative investment firm specializing in credit, private equity, real estate, and infrastructure assets.
* [MSTR (MicroStrategy Incorporated)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroStrategy): A business analytics company known for significant investments in Bitcoin as part of its corporate treasury strategy.
* [TTD (The Trade Desk, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trade_Desk): A technology company providing a platform for data-driven digital advertising management and optimization.
* [HOOD (Robinhood Markets, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinhood_Markets): A widely recognized fintech firm with significant retail investor engagement and growing product diversification.
* [DDOG (Datadog, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datadog): A cloud-native monitoring and analytics platform that has shown strong growth and relevance in enterprise infrastructure.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'HOOD'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

Each subquestion will resolve as **Yes** if the corresponding company is announced to be officially added to the S\&P 500 Index before October 1, 2025, according to [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://www.spglobal.com/).
question_details.fine_print:
* Subquestions will resolve based on official announcements from S\&P Dow Jones Indices that a company will be added. The actual inclusion of the company to the index is not required for resolution.
* Potential retractions or cancellations of an inclusion announcement will not affect the resolution of subquestions.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Strategy Snubbed as Robinhood, Emcor, AppLovin Join S&P 500**
Shares of Strategy (NASDAQ:MSTR) slid nearly 2% after the company was omitted from the S&P 500, despite meeting all eligibility criteria, including a market value of about $95 billion, ample liquidity, positive GAAP earnings and a $10 billion net income in Q2 2025 largely driven by a $14 billion unrealized gain on 638,460 bitcoins. Instead, S&P Dow Jones Indices announced that AppLovin (NASDAQ:APP), Robinhood Markets (NASDAQ:HOOD) and Emcor Group (NYSE:EME) would join the index. Analysts cited heavy reliance on Bitcoin, the fact that Strategy had only one full year of GAAP profitability, and the committee’s cautious history as possible reasons for the exclusion. Benchmark’s Mark Palmer said 'the exclusion reflected the committee’s cautious stance rather than Strategy’s balance sheet', adding that the company remains a strong contender for future inclusion if profits hold. Jeff Walton of Strive Funds noted that Strategy’s Q2 profits were 6.6 times higher than the three added firms combined and 2.5 times greater over the past year, making its exclusion difficult to justify. After the announcement, MSTR fell 1.78% to $329.90, while Robinhood surged 15.8% to $117.28.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 09, 2025 07:05 PM
Source:[ValueWalk](https://www.valuewalk.com/news/strategy-snubbed-as-robinhood-emcor-applovin-join-sp-500/)

**Strategy Misses S&P 500 Inclusion This Month: Will It Ever Make the Cut?**
The article reports that Bitcoin treasury company Strategy (MSTR) was omitted from the S&P 500 during the latest index rebalancing, while AppLovin (APP), Robinhood (HOOD), and Emcor (EME) were added. Strategy meets the index’s eligibility criteria—U.S. domicile, market cap of at least $22.7 billion, profitability in the most recent quarter and over the last year, and sufficient public float—but the S&P Index Committee also weighs sector weighting and other factors. The committee’s decision is confidential, and the article notes that the committee added several bitcoin‑owning firms to the index this year, suggesting Strategy could be included in a future rebalancing if a spot opens. The piece cites Bloomberg ETF analyst James Seyffart, who estimates $22 trillion is tied to S&P‑500‑based products, and Stephens, which projected that fund managers would need to purchase about 50 million Strategy shares worth roughly $16 billion if the company were added. Strategy’s $10 billion profit from bitcoin price gains in the last quarter is highlighted as evidence of its eligibility. The article quotes former committee chair David Blitzer, who said the committee’s goal is "to have an index that really is a great measure of the market," adding that the index should mirror market movements. No opinion or loaded language is present, and the article sticks to factual reporting.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 09, 2025 05:19 PM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/strategy-misses-p-500-inclusion-171949092.html)

**NY Stock Market Closes Higher on Rate Cut Expectations**
On September 8, 2025, the New York Stock Exchange closed higher across all three major indices amid expectations of a Fed rate cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 45,514.95, up 114.09 points (0.25%). The S&P 500 closed at 6,495.15, up 13.65 points (0.21%). The Nasdaq Composite reached 21,798.699, up 98.311 points (0.45%).

The rally followed a weak August non‑farm payroll report and the Fed’s “blackout” period before the September FOMC meeting, which has increased speculation that the Fed will lower rates. According to CME FedWatch, the probability of a 75‑basis‑point cut by December rose to 69.3% from 65.3% the previous day.

Investors are now focused on the upcoming August Producer Price Index (PPI) on the 11th and the Consumer Price Index (CPI) on the 12th, as a sharp inflation rebound could slow the pace of cuts. "If inflation does not rise sharply this week, the Fed’s cut is essentially confirmed," said Chris Larkin of iTrade, adding that the market will likely remain cautious until the CPI release.

Tech stocks showed mixed performance: Nvidia (+0.77%), Amazon (+1.51%), and Microsoft (+0.65%) gained modestly, while Apple (‑0.76%), Meta (‑0.02%), Alphabet (‑0.34%), and Tesla (‑1.27%) fell. Broadcom (+3.21%) and Palantir (+1.95%) continued to rally.

Individual stocks surged on index‑inclusion news: Robinhood jumped 15.83% and Apple‑Robinhood 11.59% after being added to the S&P 500. In contrast, MicroStrategy, a Bitcoin‑holding company expected to be added, fell 1.78% after the inclusion was canceled.

Other changes include Uber Technologies (UBER) joining the S&P 100, replacing Charter Communications (CHTR); MP Materials (MP) and Kratos Defense & Security (KTOS) moving into the S&P MidCap 400; and several firms—Wendy’s (WEN), MarketAxess, Caesars, Enphase, Acadia Healthcare (ACHC), and ManpowerGroup (MAN)—transitioning to the S&P SmallCap 600. The reshuffle is expected to trigger significant stock moves as passive investors adjust portfolios.

**S&P 500 Potential: Strategy Could See $16 Billion Inflows With Index Inclusion-Bloomberg | Bitcoinist.com**
Strategy, formerly MicroStrategy, has become a major Bitcoin holder, generating a $14 billion unrealized gain in the last quarter, which Bloomberg reports satisfies the profitability requirement for S&P 500 inclusion.  If the company were accepted, passive index‑tracking funds would need to purchase roughly 50 million shares, creating an estimated $16 billion inflow at current market prices.  The S&P 500 committee evaluates liquidity, profitability, trading history, and sector balance; it requires a minimum market capitalization of $22.7 billion and positive income for the current and past four quarters.  Strategy’s market cap exceeds $90 billion, comfortably above the threshold.  The technology sector dominates the index, and recent additions such as Coinbase Global and Block (founded by Jack Dorsey) signal growing recognition of digital assets.  Melissa Roberts, managing director at Stephens, noted that ‘If someone is a big player in the space, it’s hard to ignore them.’  Nonetheless, skepticism remains about the sustainability of Strategy’s corporate‑treasury model, which raises capital through debt and equity to acquire Bitcoin.  Shares fell 17 % in August, eroding the premium over Bitcoin holdings, and the 30‑day price volatility reached 96 %, higher than that of Nvidia or Tesla, potentially raising red flags for the committee.  Although Strategy was included in the Nasdaq 100 last December, the S&P 500 is larger, with nearly $10 trillion tied to passive strategies.  Saylor has suggested that 2025 could be a pivotal year for inclusion.

**MicroStrategy Qualifies for S&P 500, Inclusion Decision Awaiting Friday**
MicroStrategy (ticker MSTR), now trading under the name Strategy, has officially qualified for potential inclusion in the S&P 500 after reporting its strongest quarterly performance ever. As of June 30, the company held 597,325 BTC, generating a 19.7 % year‑to‑date BTC yield, a key KPI that measures bitcoin growth relative to diluted shares. In Q2 2025, Strategy posted operating income of $14 billion and net income of $10 billion, translating to diluted earnings per share of $32.6. Quarterly revenue reached $114.5 million, up 2.7 % YoY, while subscription services grew by almost 70 %. The shift to fair‑value accounting in January 2025 allowed the firm to recognize unrealised gains on its digital‑asset holdings, boosting profitability. Management has raised its 2025 full‑year outlook to operating income of $34 billion, net income of $24 billion, and diluted EPS of $80, assuming a year‑end BTC price of $150 k. Strategy meets all S&P 500 criteria: U.S. listing, market cap above $8.2 billion, daily volume over 250,000 shares, public float over 50 %, and positive earnings in the last quarter and trailing 12 months. The next potential inclusion window is the September 2025 rebalancing, with announcements on September 5 and effective changes on September 19. If admitted, it would be the first bitcoin‑reserve company to join the benchmark, marking a historic moment for digital‑asset integration in U.S. equities.
